#Text=3. Proposed Solution
#Text=3.1 .
#Text=Overall Scheme
#Text=In this paper , we propose a solution to the problem formulated in Section 2 , using histogram matching and the endmember abundance optimization process proposed in Lanaras et al. .
#Text=As briefly explained in Section 1 , defined a high-resolution HSI as a factorization of spectral endmembers and its per-pixel abundance .
#Text=The authors of find a high-resolution HSI by optimizing the spectral endmembers to a low-resolution HSI , and the per-pixel endmember abundances to a high-resolution RGB , image .
#Text=The optimization step for endmember abundance is adopted in this method to find the per-pixel endmember abundance .
#Text=The overall framework of the proposed solution is displayed in
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=.
#Text=The HSR procedure proposed in this paper consists of three steps :
#Text=Step 1 .
#Text=Creating an RGB image from a low-resolution HSI , using a spectral response function of a commercial RGB camera .
#Text=Step 2 .
#Text=Matching the histogram of a high-resolution RGB image with that of a low-resolution RGB image , obtained in Step 1 .
#Text=Step 3 .
#Text=Optimizing endmember abundance of a high-resolution HSI toward the histogram-matched high-resolution RGB image obtained in Step 2 .
#Text=In Step 1 , a low-resolution RGB image is reconstructed from a low-resolution HSI by factorizing a spectral response function of a commercial RGB camera .
#Text=The reconstructed low-resolution RGB image is used as a color distribution standard point for both the low-resolution HSI and high-resolution RGB image .
#Text=In Step 2 , the histogram of the high-resolution RGB image is matched with the low-resolution RGB image obtained in Step 1 .
#Text=Since the high-resolution RGB image has the same color distribution as the low-resolution RGB image , it is less necessary to match the color distribution using an optimization process .

#Text=In Step 3 , the per-pixel endmember abundance optimization process of is adopted , to match the spatial distribution of endmember abundance between the high-resolution HSI and the high-resolution RGB image .

#Text=The per-pixel endmember abundance optimization is performed by reducing the subtraction between the target high-resolution RGB image and the high-resolution RGB image obtained from the high-resolution HSI .

#Text=Because this optimization process disregards the objective function , representing the difference between low- and high-resolution HSIs , the endmember abundance freely converges to the pixel location of the high-resolution RGB image .
#Text=Each part of the proposed method is formulated as explained below .
#Text=Step 1 factorizes the spectral response function of a RGB camera with a low-resolution HSI to reconstruct a low-resolution RGB image .

#Text=An RGB image is reconstructed the equation formulated in : ( 5 ) where ) is the spectral response function of an camera for each channel of RGB , is spectral power distribution of an illuminant and is a spectral reflectance of a point in an image .
#Text=Equation ( 5 ) can also be written in a matrix form , for a discrete summation along the spectral range of a hyperspectral camera with a given bandwidth .
#Text=Step 2 matches the histogram of an RGB image to that of a low-resolution RGB image L , obtained from an HSI .

#Text=The histogram-matching process is a minimization of grayscale transformation T in the following equation : ( 6 ) where is a specific index on a gray scale , is the cumulative distribution function of L ’ s histogram and is the cumulative distribution function of I ’ s histogram for all intensities k on a gray scale .
#Text=Since the histogram equalization is defined on a gray scale , it has to be iteratively performed on each channel of a RGB image .
#Text=T is a function that finds the index on that has the value most similar to the value of at a particular index on grayscale .
#Text=After the function T is defined for g on all intensities on a gray scale , histogram equalization is performed by finding and mapping a value corresponding to L in the input image I , using T .
#Text=In Step 3 of the proposed algorithm , an estimate of Z , or equivalently E and A , is needed .

#Text=From the given super-resolution problem , the following constrained least-squares problem is formulated as : ( 7a ) ( 7b ) with denoting the Frobenius norm , and is elements of A and constrained to non-negative values .
#Text=3.2 .
#Text=Overall Algorithm and Implementation
#Text=The method proposed in Section 3.1 proceeds with the following procedure , as described in Table 1 .
#Text=The algorithm requires H and I , which are low-resolution HSI and high-resolution RGB images , respectively .
#Text=Because Z will be reconstructed using endmember abundance with the same resolution as I , the resolution of I has to be an integer multiple of the resolution of H with upsampling rate S .
#Text=Additionally , RGB camera sensitivity C is required to reconstruct an RGB image from H .
